questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions  Have you noticed how, when crossing a busy road, you feel a sudden urge to speed up and melt into the crowd? Whether you are in Rio de Janeiro or Bangkok, New Delhi or New York City, your animal instinct tells you that it is safer to ___________ as part of a herd than on your own. Fear brings us closer together. The evidence is not just anecdotal. When we are herding, neuroimaging experiments show increased activation in the amygdala area of the brain, where fear and other negative emotions are processed. While you may feel vulnerable and exposed on your own, being part of the herd gives you a distinct sense of protection. You know in your guts that, in the midst of others, the risk of being hit by a car is lower because it is somehow distributed among the group’s members. The more of them, the lower the risk. There is safety in numbers. And so much more than mere safety.  Herding also comes with an intoxicating sense of power: as members of a crowd, we feel much stronger and braver than we are in fact. And sometimes we act accordingly. The same person who, on his own, wouldn’t ‘hurt a fly’ will not hesitate to set a government building on fire or rob a liquor store when part of an angry mass. The most mild-mannered of us can make the meanest comments as part of an online mob. A herd can do wonders of psychological transformation in its individual members; in no time, prudence turns into folly, caution into recklessness, decency into savagery. Once caught up in the maelstrom, it is extremely difficult to hold back: you see it as your duty to participate. Any act of lynching, ancient or modern, literal or on social media, displays this feature. ‘A murder shared with many others, which is not only safe and permitted, but indeed recommended, is irresistible to the great majority of men,’ writes Elias Canetti in Crowds and Power (1960).  The herd can also give its members a disproportionate sense of personal worth. No matter how empty or miserable their individual existence may otherwise be, belonging to a certain group makes them feel accepted and recognised – even respected. There is no hole in one’s personal life, no matter how big, that one’s intense devotion to one’s tribe cannot fill, no trauma that it does not seem to heal. That’s why cults and gangs, fringe organisations or sects hold such an extraordinary appeal: to a disoriented soul, they can offer a sense of fulfilment and recognition that neither family nor friends nor profession can supply. A crowd can be therapeutic in the same way in which a highly toxic substance can have curative powers.  Herding, then, engenders a paradoxical form of identity: you are somebody not despite the fact that you’ve melted into the crowd, but because of it. You may be nobody on your own, and your life an empty shell, yet once you’ve managed to establish a meaningful connection with the herd, its volcanic, boundless life overflows into yours and more than fulfills it. You will not be able to find yourself in the crowd, but that’s the least of your worries: you are now part of something that feels so much grander and nobler than your poor self. Your connection with the life of the herd not only fills an inner vacuum but adds a sense of purpose to your disoriented existence. And the more individuals bring their disorientedness to the party, the livelier it gets. And all the more dangerous.

Any act of lynching, ancient or modern, literal or on social media, displays this feature. ‘A murder shared with many others, which is not only safe and permitted, but indeed recommended, is irresistible to the great majority of men,’ writes Elias Canetti in Crowds and Power (1960).  The herd can also give its members a disproportionate sense of personal worth. No matter how empty or miserable their individual existence may otherwise be, belonging to a certain group makes them feel accepted and recognised – even respected. There is no hole in one’s personal life, no matter how big, that one’s intense devotion to one’s tribe cannot fill, no trauma that it does not seem to heal. That’s why cults and gangs, fringe organisations or sects hold such an extraordinary appeal: to a disoriented soul, they can offer a sense of fulfilment and recognition that neither family nor friends nor profession can supply. A crowd can be therapeutic in the same way in which a highly toxic substance can have curative powers.  Herding, then, engenders a paradoxical form of identity: you are somebody not despite the fact that you’ve melted into the crowd, but because of it. You may be nobody on your own, and your life an empty shell, yet once you’ve managed to establish a meaningful connection with the herd, its volcanic, boundless life overflows into yours and more than fulfills it. You will not be able to find yourself in the crowd, but that’s the least of your worries: you are now part of something that feels so much grander and nobler than your poor self. Your connection with the life of the herd not only fills an inner vacuum but adds a sense of purpose to your disoriented existence. And the more individuals bring their disorientedness to the party, the livelier it gets. And all the more dangerous.

There is safety in numbers. And so much more than mere safety.  Herding also comes with an intoxicating sense of power: as members of a crowd, we feel much stronger and braver than we are in fact. And sometimes we act accordingly. The same person who, on his own, wouldn’t ‘hurt a fly’ will not hesitate to set a government building on fire or rob a liquor store when part of an angry mass. The most mild-mannered of us can make the meanest comments as part of an online mob. A herd can do wonders of psychological transformation in its individual members; in no time, prudence turns into folly, caution into recklessness, decency into savagery. Once caught up in the maelstrom, it is extremely difficult to hold back: you see it as your duty to participate. Any act of lynching, ancient or modern, literal or on social media, displays this feature. ‘A murder shared with many others, which is not only safe and permitted, but indeed recommended, is irresistible to the great majority of men,’ writes Elias Canetti in Crowds and Power (1960).  The herd can also give its members a disproportionate sense of personal worth. No matter how empty or miserable their individual existence may otherwise be, belonging to a certain group makes them feel accepted and recognised – even respected. There is no hole in one’s personal life, no matter how big, that one’s intense devotion to one’s tribe cannot fill, no trauma that it does not seem to heal. That’s why cults and gangs, fringe organisations or sects hold such an extraordinary appeal: to a disoriented soul, they can offer a sense of fulfilment and recognition that neither family nor friends nor profession can supply. A crowd can be therapeutic in the same way in which a highly toxic substance can have curative powers.  Herding, then, engenders a paradoxical form of identity: you are somebody not despite the fact that you’ve melted into the crowd, but because of it. You may be nobody on your own, and your life an empty shell, yet once you’ve managed to establish a meaningful connection with the herd, its volcanic, boundless life overflows into yours and more than fulfills it. You will not be able to find yourself in the crowd, but that’s the least of your worries: you are now part of something that feels so much grander and nobler than your poor self. Your connection with the life of the herd not only fills an inner vacuum but adds a sense of purpose to your disoriented existence. And the more individuals bring their disorientedness to the party, the livelier it gets. And all the more dangerous.

questions.question_text_1: Read the following conversation and answer the given subquestions:  Karan: Right, so shall we discuss what we have to do for this project then? Lavanya: Yes, it says we have to ‘Investigate some aspect of the university facilities’. Paul: Yeah, we have to design a questionnaire, don’t we? Lavanya: Yes. And we have to write a report and do a presentation. Paul: How long does it have to be? 1000 words, isn’t it? Lavanya: Let me see. The report has to be between 1000 and 1500 words, and we have to do that on our own, but we do the presentation and the investigation as a group. Lavanya: So, have you got any ideas about what we can investigate? Karan: I know one of the other groups is looking at the university library and whether it’s adequate for student needs. Paul: Yes, and one group’s doing the sports center. Karan: I was wondering about investigating transport. Paul: Transport? Lavanya: Yes, we could look at whether people think the bus service is regular enough, and we could also look at car parking facilities. Paul: We could look at the cycle parking facilities too. There’s never enough space for all the cycles in the cycle sheds. I’m sure the university could afford to build more, what with all the fees we pay. Karan: OK, I’m happy with that idea. So, how should we go about the investigation then? Lavanya: Well, we could make some questionnaires. I can ask the people who travel on buses, and Paul, you can ask cyclists, and Karan, you do a questionnaire for car drivers.  Karan: Shouldn’t we write the questions together, rather than individually? Lavanya: Yes, that’s what I meant, we can write the questionnaires together, but each of us can be responsible for carrying out the questionnaires individually. Does that sound okay?  Karan: It sounds good. Okay, well, let’s think about these questions then.

questions.question_text_1: Fill in the blanks with correct expressions of numbers/values/quantity  With the Indian economy returning back to normal and with consumption levels at an all-time high, the country has seen rapid growth in the demand for frontline workers. (1)__________________ than 8 million jobs were created in the frontline industry in FY 2022. With rising retail consumption in a post-pandemic economy, Q2 of FY 2022 saw a (2) ________________ rise in demand for frontline workers because of a rapid increase in jobs in the delivery and retail segments. E-commerce contributed the highest to the demand for frontline workers followed by logistics and mobility. Maharashtra, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh/Telangana and Tamil Nadu have the (3)______________ supply of and demand for frontline workers in India. Sixty (4)____________ of the total frontline workers belong to these states and 65% of the total demand comes from these states. Mumbai has been the (5)__________________ contributor and demand for frontline workers at 24.7% and 20.9%, respectively.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Refusing a sweet that your colleague is offering you on a special occasion.
question_texts: Refusing a sweet that your colleague is offering you on a special occasion.

options.option_text: Sweets are for lazy sloths, and I sure ain’t one.
Sweets make you prone to obesity, which in turn increases chances of yougetting cancer. And we all know how deadly cancer can be. So no, I don’t want the sweet. Sorry.

Thank you for offering me this, but I am really sorry as I have to decline this. Itis just that I have the opposite of a sweet tooth, and ghee-based sweets tend to give me allergies.Hope you’ll understand. Thanks a lot again, and best wishes.

questions.question_text_1: Read the following E-mail and answer the given subquestions  From: John Samuel johns@gmail.com To: Michael Davis michaeld@gmail.com  Sub: __________ ___________,  I enjoyed speaking with you the other day at the interview for the copywriter. The job appears to be an ideal match for my skills, ambitions, and interests.  The innovative approach to the corporate culture within the advertising world confirmed my wish to work at your firm. Thank you for taking the time to interview me for the copywriter profile at Dream Big Entertainments. I have a high level of interest in working for your firm and look forward to hearing from you.  Best regards,  John

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"Foundation Level: Semester 2: English 2"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships between key themes.

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
The exam covers **4 major areas**:
1. **Reading Comprehension** (Passages + Vocabulary)
2. **Listening Comprehension** (Audio-based questions)
3. **Grammar & Syntax** (Sentence structure, tenses, clauses, etc.)
4. **Professional & Social Communication** (Emails, dialogues, discourse markers, etc.)

---

## **1. Reading Comprehension**
### **Key Themes from the Passage ("Herding Behavior")**
- **Psychological & Social Dynamics of Crowds**:
  - **Safety in Numbers**: Risk distribution in groups (e.g., crossing roads).
  - **Amygdala Activation**: Brain’s fear response in herding situations.
  - **Paradoxical Identity**: Losing individuality but gaining purpose in a crowd.
  - **Behavioral Transformation**:
    - Prudence → Folly
    - Caution → Recklessness
    - Decency → Savagery
  - **Power of the Herd**:
    - Strength in numbers (e.g., protests, mobs).
    - Disproportionate sense of worth (e.g., cults, gangs).
  - **Therapeutic vs. Dangerous Aspects**:
    - Fills emotional voids but can lead to extremism.

### **Vocabulary & Synonyms**
| Word          | Synonyms/Antonyms                     | Contextual Meaning                          |
|---------------|---------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|
| Venture       | Dare, undertake                       | To proceed despite risk (e.g., "venture as part of a herd"). |
| Vulnerable    | Insecure, exposed                     | Lacking protection.                        |
| Maelstrom     | Whirlpool, chaos                       | A turbulent situation.                    |
| Transcendence | Sublimity, paramountcy (≠ mundane)     | Surpassing ordinary limits.                |
| Achievement   | Accomplishment (≠ failure)            | Successful completion of a goal.          |

---

## **2. Listening Comprehension**
### **Key Topics from Audio Clips**
- **Sports & Achievements**:
  - **EGOT**: Winning an **Emmy, Grammy, Oscar, Tony** (only **11 people** have achieved this).
  - **Ironman Triathlon**: Swimming (2.4 miles), cycling (**112 miles**), running (26.2 miles = marathon).
  - **Self-Transcendence Race**: **41 days** (Wolfgang Schwerk’s record).
- **Synonyms & Phrasal Verbs**:
  - **Transcendence ≠ Mundane** (ordinary).
  - **Competitive = Ambitious**.
  - **Wear out**: Become useless due to overuse.

---

## **3. Grammar & Syntax**
### **Core Concepts & Rules**
#### **A. Sentence Structure**
| Type               | Definition                          | Example                                      |
|--------------------|-------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------|
| **Simple**         | 1 independent clause.               | "The day after tomorrow is a holiday."       |
| **Compound**       | 2+ independent clauses (FANBOYS).  | "He is funny, **yet** he is very polite."    |
| **Complex**        | 1 independent + 1+ dependent clause.| "The articles **that I bought** are damaged."|
| **Conditional**    | Hypothetical situations.            | **Zero**: "If water boils, it turns to steam."|
|                    |                                     | **First**: "If it rains, we **will** cancel."|
|                    |                                     | **Second**: "If I **were** you, I’d study."  |

#### **B. Verb Tenses & Moods**
| Tense/Mood         | Example                              | Keywords                     |
|--------------------|--------------------------------------|------------------------------|
| **Past Perfect**   | "He **had listened** to his siblings."| "Had + V3"                   |
| **Subjunctive**    | "If I **were** you..."               | Hypothetical/wishes.         |
| **Indicative**     | "This is my friend."                 | States facts.                |
| **Imperative**     | "Listen to me."                      | Commands.                    |

#### **C. Clauses & Phrases**
| Type               | Example                              | Function                     |
|--------------------|--------------------------------------|------------------------------|
| **Relative Clause**| "The articles **that I bought**..."  | Modifies a noun.             |
| **Adverbial Phrase**| "He would make it **to the sea**."  | Describes place/manner/time. |
| **Adjunct**        | "**In the afternoons**, we have tea."| Optional adverbial element.  |

#### **D. Conjunctions**
| Type               | Examples                            | Function                     |
|--------------------|-------------------------------------|------------------------------|
| **Subordinating**  | Because, unless, before             | Introduces dependent clauses.|
| **Coordinating**   | And, but, or (FANBOYS)              | Joins independent clauses.   |

#### **E. Modals & Question Tags**
| Modal              | Example                              | Meaning                      |
|--------------------|--------------------------------------|------------------------------|
| **Must**           | "The exam **must** be tough."         | Logical certainty.           |
| **Could**          | "The play **could** start late."     | Possibility.                 |
| **Question Tags**  | "It is well done, **isn’t it**?"     | Confirmation (↑ for rising intonation). |

#### **F. Prefixes & Suffixes**
- **"Unhappy"**: **2 prefixes** (un- + happy).
- **"Rendezvous"**: Meet at an agreed time.

---

## **4. Professional & Social Communication**
### **A. Emails**
- **Structure**:
  - **Subject Line**: Clear and specific (e.g., *"Letter of Gratitude (for Job Interview)"*).
  - **Salutation**:
    - Formal: *"Dear Dr. Davis,"* (if recipient has a title).
    - Semi-formal: *"Dear Michael,"*.
    - **Punctuation**: Colon (:) or comma (,) after salutation.
  - **Body**: Concise, polite, and professional.
  - **Closing**: *"Best regards,"* or *"Sincerely,"*.
- **Key Points**:
  - Emails are **rewritable** (unlike live speech) and can serve as **legal evidence**.
  - **Not temporary** (can be stored/forwarded).

### **B. Dialogues & Social Contexts**
| Scenario                          | Appropriate Response                          | Avoid                          |
|-----------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|--------------------------------|
| **Reminding a colleague**         | "I wanted to give you a gentle reminder..."   | Accusatory language ("Why haven’t you finished?"). |
| **Inviting to a party**           | "Hi, tomorrow is my birthday. Will you drop by?" | Overly casual ("Hey, got a party. Mind coming?"). |
| **Declining food**                | "Thank you, but I’m allergic to ghee."        | Rude refusals ("Sweets are for lazy sloths."). |
| **Requesting help**               | "Sir, would you please review this FIR?"      | Overly submissive ("Your majesty, please fix this."). |

### **C. Discourse Markers**
- **Purpose**: Signal shifts in conversation.
- **Examples**:
  - *"First of all,"* (introduction).
  - *"I mean,"* (clarification).

### **D. Figurative Language**
- **Simile**: Direct comparison using *"like"* or *"as"* (e.g., *"dead as a doornail"*).

---

## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **1. Reading Comprehension: Herding Behavior**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Herding Behavior] --> B[Psychological Effects]
    A --> C[Social Dynamics]
    B --> B1[Safety in Numbers]
    B --> B2[Amygdala Activation]
    B --> B3[Risk Distribution]
    C --> C1[Power of the Crowd]
    C --> C2[Identity Paradox]
    C --> C3[Behavioral Transformation]
    C1 --> C1a[Strength in Groups]
    C1 --> C1b[Extremism]
    C2 --> C2a[Loss of Individuality]
    C2 --> C2b[Purpose in Belonging]
    C3 --> C3a[Prudence → Folly]
    C3 --> C3b[Decency → Savagery]
```

### **2. Grammar & Syntax**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Grammar] --> B[Sentence Structure]
    A --> C[Tenses & Moods]
    A --> D[Clauses]
    A --> E[Conjunctions]
    B --> B1[Simple]
    B --> B2[Compound]
    B --> B3[Complex]
    C --> C1[Past Perfect: had + V3]
    C --> C2[Subjunctive: If I were...]
    D --> D1[Relative: that/which]
    D --> D2[Adverbial: to the sea]
    E --> E1[Subordinating: because]
    E --> E2[Coordinating: FANBOYS]
```

### **3. Professional Communication**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Professional Communication] --> B[Emails]
    A --> C[Dialogues]
    B --> B1[Subject Line]
    B --> B2[Salutation]
    B --> B3[Body]
    B --> B4[Closing]
    C --> C1[Politeness]
    C --> C2[Contextual Appropriateness]
    C --> C3[Avoid Rudeness]
```

### **4. Listening Comprehension: Sports & Achievements**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Sports & Achievements] --> B[EGOT]
    A --> C[Ironman Triathlon]
    A --> D[Self-Transcendence Race]
    B --> B1[Emmy, Grammy, Oscar, Tony]
    B --> B2[Only 11 people]
    C --> C1[Swim 2.4 miles]
    C --> C2[Cycle 112 miles]
    C --> C3[Run 26.2 miles]
    D --> D1[41 days]
```

---
### **Key Equations (for Math-Related Questions)**
*(Note: This exam has no mathematical equations, but if included, they would cover basic statistics like risk distribution in herding behavior.)*

---
### **Exam Tips**
1. **Reading Comprehension**:
   - Skim for **main ideas**, then scan for **details**.
   - Note **synonyms/antonyms** for vocabulary questions.
2. **Listening**:
   - Focus on **numbers, names, and key terms** (e.g., EGOT, Ironman distances).
3. **Grammar**:
   - Memorize **tenses, clauses, and conjunctions**.
   - Practice **rewriting sentences** (e.g., direct → indirect speech).
4. **Communication**:
   - **Emails**: Follow formal structure.
   - **Dialogues**: Match tone to context (polite/professional).
